verses.text: Dishonest scales are detestable to the Lord, but a just weight is his delight.
verses.comment: Ancient trade relied on physical scales, so this proverb shows God’s concern for economic justice and integrity. Themes of justice repeat throughout Scripture, calling for honesty in all dealings.

verses.text: When pride comes, then comes shame; but wisdom dwells with the humble.
verses.comment: Humility is frequently praised as a precondition for wisdom. Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 23:12 echoes this call to humility.

verses.text: The honesty of the upright guides them, but the deceitfulness of the unfaithful destroys them.
verses.comment: Upright living offers guidance. This mirrors the concept of the conscience acting as a spiritual compass, seen in Romans 2:15.

verses.text: Wealth is useless in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.
verses.comment: Material resources cannot save in God’s judgment; only a righteous life brings hope. This looks forward to eschatological themes, as Christ’s righteousness alone secures eternal life.

verses.text: The righteousness of the blameless makes their way straight, but the wicked fall by their own wickedness.
verses.comment: Living rightly guides one’s steps. Compare this with Christ’s assertion that He is the Way (John 14:6), inviting participation in His righteousness.

verses.text: The upright are rescued by their righteousness, but the faithless are trapped by their own desires.
verses.comment: Righteousness here is portrayed as salvific. This has both a literal and spiritual meaning: a holy life protects, but spiritual desires away from God enslave.

verses.text: When the wicked die, their hope perishes; all their confidence in power comes to nothing.
verses.comment: Earthly and selfish hopes are temporary; only hope placed in God is eternal (cf. 1 Cor. 15:19).

verses.text: The righteous are delivered from trouble, and the wicked take their place.
verses.comment: A reversal of fortune is a common biblical motif. The innocent receive God’s reward, as Jesus teaches about the last being first (see Matt. 20:16).

verses.text: By their mouth the godless destroy their neighbors, but the righteous are rescued by knowledge.
verses.comment: Words are powerful to harm or heal. Knowledge of God’s truth brings salvation—pointing to Christ who is ‘the Word’ incarnate (John 1:1).

verses.text: When the righteous prosper, the city rejoices; when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.
verses.comment: Righteousness benefits the whole community. The joy echoes Luke 15:7, where heaven rejoices over one sinner who repents.

verses.text: By the blessing of the upright a city is exalted, but it is torn down by the mouth of the wicked.
verses.comment: God’s people serve as a blessing to society, reminiscent of Abraham’s calling in Genesis 12:2-3.

verses.text: He who despises his neighbor lacks sense, but a person of understanding holds their tongue.
verses.comment: This encourages charity and control over speech, both valued in Christ’s call to love neighbor as self (Matt. 22:39).

verses.text: A gossip betrays secrets, but one of faithful spirit keeps things hidden.
verses.comment: Faithfulness is critical for community life, a theme seen in Paul's exhortations regarding speech (Eph. 4:29).

verses.text: Where there is no guidance, a people fall; but in the multitude of counselors there is safety.
verses.comment: This underlines the importance of communal wisdom and leadership—a principle affirmed by the pattern of apostolic guidance in Acts.

verses.text: Whoever guarantees a loan for a stranger will suffer, but whoever avoids such pledges is secure.
verses.comment: Scripture warns about rash promises. Wise stewardship avoids unnecessary risk—a concept echoed by Jesus’ teaching in Luke 14:28-31.

verses.text: A gracious woman gains honor, and ruthless men take wealth.
verses.comment: Honor flows from virtue. Contrary to worldly power, Scripture upholds grace and integrity as true sources of greatness.

verses.text: A kind person benefits themselves, but a cruel person brings trouble on their own flesh.
verses.comment: True charity is not only for others but forms the soul. This supports a spiritual principle that love brings grace—a notable theme in Christ’s beatitudes (Matt. 5:7).

verses.text: The wicked earns deceptive wages, but whoever sows righteousness gets a sure reward.
verses.comment: Rewards are lasting only if grounded in righteousness. Paul echoes this: 'whatever one sows, that will he also reap.'

verses.text: Genuine righteousness leads to life, but pursuing evil leads to death.
verses.comment: This points forward to the spiritual truth expounded by Paul: the wages of sin is death, but God's gift is eternal life.

verses.text: Those crooked in heart are despised by the Lord, but those blameless in their ways are his delight.
verses.comment: God’s delight in blamelessness anticipates Jesus’ call to purity of heart (Matt. 5:8).

verses.text: Be sure of this: the evil will not go unpunished, but the descendants of the righteous will be delivered.
verses.comment: God’s justice is certain, but he is also faithful to those who walk in righteousness. This alludes to God’s covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: Like a gold ring in a pig’s snout is a beautiful woman lacking discretion.
verses.comment: External beauty without inner virtue is empty. This is developed in the praise of the wise woman in Proverbs 31.

verses.text: The desire of the righteous ends only in good, but the expectation of the wicked leads to wrath.
verses.comment: This contrast of desires echoes Jesus’ teaching that those who seek God will be satisfied.

verses.text: One gives freely, yet grows richer; another withholds what should be given, and ends in poverty.
verses.comment: Generosity is paradoxically fruitful. Christ’s teaching (Luke 6:38) similarly promises blessing for those who give.

verses.text: A generous soul will prosper, and whoever refreshes others will be refreshed.
verses.comment: Generosity is rewarded by God. This Spiritual Law is echoed in Jesus’ statements about mercy and reward in the Sermon on the Mount.

verses.text: People curse the one who hoards grain, but blessing is on the head of those who sell it.
verses.comment: Economic justice and charity—here in food—are blessed, showing God’s concern for the poor and needy.

verses.text: He who diligently seeks good finds favor, but evil comes to those who search for it.
verses.comment: Seeking good brings favor—grace—which is ultimately fulfilled in the searching after God (Matt. 7:7).

verses.text: Those who trust in riches will fall, but the righteous will thrive like green leaves.
verses.comment: Material dependence is vanity; faith gives life. Compare with Jesus’ warnings about riches (Mark 10:24-25).

verses.text: Whoever troubles his own household will inherit wind, and the foolish will be servant to the wise.
verses.comment: Actions against one’s family ultimately bring emptiness; wisdom prevails in the end—a prefiguration of the reversal of fortunes in the Gospel.

verses.text: The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and one who wins souls is wise.
verses.comment: The tree of life image recalls Eden and eternal life in Christ. ‘Winning souls’ foreshadows the evangelical mission given by Jesus (Matt. 28:19).

verses.text: If the righteous are repaid on earth, how much more the wicked and the sinner!
verses.comment: God’s justice is experienced even in this life, but future judgment exceeds this. Peter refers to this reality in his discussion of suffering for righteousness.
